title: Electoral district of Riverton
text:
Riverton is a <a href="Western%20Australian%20Legislative%20Assembly">Legislative Assembly</a> <a href="Electoral%20districts%20of%20Western%20Australia">electorate</a> in the <a href="states%20and%20territories%20of%20Australia">state</a> of <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a>. Riverton is named for the southern <a href="Perth">Perth</a> suburb of <a href="Riverton%2C%20Western%20Australia">Riverton</a> which falls within its borders.
History.
Riverton was created at the 1988 redistribution, replacing the abolished district of <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Clontarf">Clontarf</a>, which had been a safe <a href="Liberal%20Party%20of%20Australia%20%28Western%20Australian%20Division%29">Liberal</a> seat since a redistribution prior to the <a href="1977%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">1977 election</a>. Riverton was first contested at the <a href="1989%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">1989 election</a>, at which Liberal Party member <a href="Graham%20Kierath">Graham Kierath</a> was successful. He served as a minister in the <a href="Richard%20Court">Court</a> government, and held the seat until his unexpected defeat at the <a href="2001%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">2001 election</a> on a 10.16% swing. The seat was then held by <a href="Tony%20McRae%20%28politician%29">Tony McRae</a> of the <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party%20%28Western%20Australian%20Branch%29">Labor Party</a>, until his defeat by the Liberal Party's <a href="Mike%20Nahan">Mike Nahan</a> at the <a href="2008%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">2008 election</a>. McRae was the Minister for Environment, Climate Change and Disability Services between 2006 and 2008. Mike Nahan retired at the <a href="2021%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">2021 election</a>, and the seat was won back by the Labor party with a 13.3% swing towards them.
Geography.
Riverton is bounded by the <a href="Canning%20River%20%28Western%20Australia%29">Canning River</a> to the north, Bannister Creek and <a href="High%20Road%2C%20Perth">High Road</a> to the northeast, <a href="Nicholson%20Road">Nicholson Road</a> to the east, the freight railway and <a href="South%20Street%2C%20Perth">South Street</a> to the south, and Karel Avenue and Fifth Avenue to the west. Its boundaries include the suburbs of <a href="Parkwood%2C%20Western%20Australia">Parkwood</a>, <a href="Riverton%2C%20Western%20Australia">Riverton</a>, <a href="Shelley%2C%20Western%20Australia">Shelley</a>, <a href="Willetton%2C%20Western%20Australia">Willetton</a>, <a href="Bull%20Creek%2C%20Western%20Australia">Bull Creek</a> and the <a href="Canning%20Vale%2C%20Western%20Australia">Canning Vale</a> industrial area and markets.
The 2007 redistribution, which took effect at the <a href="2008%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">2008 election</a>, resulted in the seat losing <a href="Ferndale%2C%20Western%20Australia">Ferndale</a> in the northeast and eastern <a href="Leeming%2C%20Western%20Australia">Leeming</a> in the southwest, while gaining the unpopulated <a href="Canning%20Vale%2C%20Western%20Australia">Canning Vale</a> industrial area.
